'''Morality''' refers to the concept of human [[ethics]] which pertains to matters of [[good and evil]] —also referred to as "[[right]] or [[wrong]]", used within three contexts: individual [[conscience]]; systems of [[principle]]s and [[judgment]]s — sometimes called [[moral value]]s —shared within a [[cultural]], [[religion|religious]], [[secular]], [[secular humanism|Humanist]], or [[philosophical]] community; and codes of behavior or [[Code of conduct|conduct]].morality " it is the ability pre-installed in humans to define on a personal level , what is right and what is wrong. "
  +      
Personal morality defines and distinguishes among right and wrong [[intention]]s, [[motivation]]s or [[Action (philosophy)|action]]s, as these have been learned, engendered, or otherwise developed within each individual.
 
Personal morality defines and distinguishes among right and wrong [[intention]]s, [[motivation]]s or [[Action (philosophy)|action]]s, as these have been learned, engendered, or otherwise developed within each individual.
     
== Conscience, belief, and code ==
 
== Conscience, belief, and code ==
−
{{weasel}} morality => " it is the ability pre-installed in humans to define on a personal level , what is right and what is wrong. "
+
{{weasel}} [[Conscience]] refers to the impulse towards morally 'right' behavior. The actual definition of right behavior varies according to belief system. Religious belief systems usually include the idea of divine will and divine [[Last Judgment|judgment]] and usually correspond to a strict moral code of conduct. The forms of honor associated with Medieval Christian [[chivalry|knighthood]] and the forms of dress associated with some sects of [[Islam]] are examples of this.
−
[[Conscience]] refers to the impulse towards morally 'right' behavior. The actual definition of right behavior varies according to belief system. Religious belief systems usually include the idea of divine will and divine [[Last Judgment|judgment]] and usually correspond to a strict moral code of conduct. The forms of honor associated with Medieval Christian [[chivalry|knighthood]] and the forms of dress associated with some sects of [[Islam]] are examples of this.
   
Forces of social [[conformity|conform]] also significantly shape moral decisions, although the effect of cultural [[norm (sociology)|norm]]s and [[convention (norm)|custom]]s on behavior does not address what morally right behavior is.
 
Forces of social [[conformity|conform]] also significantly shape moral decisions, although the effect of cultural [[norm (sociology)|norm]]s and [[convention (norm)|custom]]s on behavior does not address what morally right behavior is.
